Package com.bluegosling.apt.reflect

This package provides an alternate set of APIs for interacting with annotations and types from an annotation processor.

See: Description

  • Interface Summary 
    Interface Description
    ArAnnotatedConstruct
    Anything that can have annotations.
    ArAnnotatedElement
    An element that can have annotations.
    ArExecutableMember
    An interface that represents a member that has executable code -- a constructor or a method.
    ArGenericDeclaration
    An element that may include the declaration of generic type variables.
    ArMember
    A member of a Java class or interface.
  • Class Summary 
    Class Description
    ArAnnotation
    An annotation in Java source code.
    ArAnnotationBridge
    Bridges an annotation mirror into an actual annotation interface.
    ArArrayType
    An array type.
    ArClass
    A class (or interface, enum, or annotation type).
    ArConstructor
    A constructor.
    ArDeclaredType
    A declared type.
    ArField
    A field.
    ArGenericMethodSignature
    Represents a generic method signature, composed of a method name and sequence of generic parameter types.
    ArMethod
    A method.
    ArMethodSignature
    Represents a method signature, composed of a method name and sequence of parameter types.
    ArPackage
    A package.
    ArParameter<M extends ArExecutableMember>
    A representation of a parameter to an executable member, like a constructor or method.
    ArPrimitiveType
    A primitive type.
    ArProcessor
    An abstract annotation processor whose methods is defined in terms of the reflection-like API in this package instead of the standard element and type mirror APIs.
    ArRoundEnvironment
    The environment for a single round of annotation processing.
    ArType
    A interface that represents a generic type.
    ArTypeParameter<D extends ArGenericDeclaration>
    A type parameter declaration.
    ArTypes
    Container of helper methods for working with ArTypes.
    ArTypeVariable
    A type variable, or a use of a type parameter.
    ArWildcardType
    A wildcard type.
  • Enum Summary 
    Enum Description
    ArClass.Kind
    An enumeration of the various kinds of classes.
    ArModifier
    Represents a modifier used in Java source code.

Package com.bluegosling.apt.reflect Description

This package provides an alternate set of APIs for interacting with annotations and types from an annotation processor. The layout of classes and interfaces here closely resembles those in java.lang.reflect, which many programmers will feel are more natural and easier to use than the APIs provided in the javax.lang.model.element and java.lang.model.type packages (aka language model APIs).

All classes in this package have names that match similar classes in the standard reflection APIs, but with an Ar prefix -- short for "Annotation processing Reflection". The prefix is meant to prevent import collisions with the actual reflection types and to prevent confusion when looking at variable declarations.

To make the most of the APIs in this package, your annotation processor should extend ArProcessor. This alternate base class provides a reference to a ArRoundEnvironment, which is very similar to the standard RoundEnvironment except that its API is defined in terms of this set of reflection APIs (instead of in terms of elements and type mirrors).

This API strives to maintain the abstraction fidelity provided by the javax.lang.model APIs, but also provide the ease-of-use provided by core reflection APIs. So, like the javax.lang.model types they wrap, the types in this API come in three flavors -- elements, types, and annotations -- which are described in more detail below.

Elements

Elements represent components of a Java program: classes, methods, fields, etc. They map to declarations in source code. They are analogous to the most commonly used types in the core reflection API: Class, Constructor, Method, and Field. In this package, they are represented by the ArAnnotatedElement type hierarchy and generally wrap javax.lang.model.element objects.

An exception to this is ArClass. Most classes do wrap a TypeElement, but this API allows usage of class tokens for primitive and array types, just like core reflection. TypeElements, on the other hand, only model declared types and thus cannot represent primitive and array types.

Types

In core reflection, there are two different way to represent types: the Type hierarchy, introduced for modeling generic types in Java 5, and the AnnotatedType hierarchy, introduced for modeling types with type annotations in Java 8. The Type hierarchy "blurred the lines" between types and elements by including a couple of classes that also represent elements: Class and TypeVariable. The java.lang.model.type APIs do not blur the lines. And because they were a cleaner separation from how elements were modeled, they did not need to introduce a parallel type hierarchy to model type annotations when Java 8 came along.

This package models types with the ArType hierarchy. Each type object wraps a TypeMirror object. The API resembles a mix of TypeMirror (from language model APIs) and AnnotatedType (from core reflection APIs), attempting to provide greater ease-of-use than type mirror while still maintaining the abstraction fidelity.

Annotations

In core reflection, annotations are instances of the annotation interface itself. In the language model APIs, there are mirrors. This package provides a blend. The ArAnnotation class is the analog of an AnnotationMirror. But annotated constructs in this package also provide the ability to create an ArAnnotationBridge, which is an implementation of an actual annotation interface with some additional static API for interacting with annotations that contains references to types that are not available during annotation processing (e.g. classes that only available in source form, and cannot be loaded as runtime types).

Differences from Core Reflection

As alluded to above, this package models types more like type mirrors. Core reflection has parallel APIs for generic types and annotated types, the former lacking the ability to model type annotations and the latter addressing that. This package, however, has only a single way to model types.

Since types are modeled more like AnnotatedType than Type, this package does not re-use class tokens and type variables for modeling both language elements and types. And, like type mirrors, it does not distinguish in the type system between declared types with type parameters and those without.

The table below shows the type in this package that is used to model the same thing that a given core reflection type models:

ContextCore ReflectionThis Package
Elements ClassArClass
TypeVariableArTypeParameter
FieldArField
ConstructorArConstructor
MethodArMethod
ParameterArParameter
PackageArPackage
Types Generic Types
ClassArDeclaredType *
ArPrimitiveType †
ArArrayType ‡
TypeVariableArTypeVariable
ParameterizedTypeArDeclaredType *
GenericArrayTypeArArrayType ‡
WildcardTypeArTypeVariable
Annotated Types
AnnotatedType §ArDeclaredType *
ArPrimitiveType †
AnnotatedTypeVariableArTypeVariable
AnnotatedParameterizedTypeArDeclaredType *
AnnotatedArrayTypeArArrayType
AnnotatedWildcardTypeArWildcardType
  • * This package models all declared types, whether they have parameters or not, using the same ArDeclaredType. It is a parameterized type if it has type arguments.
  • † This package models declared reference types differently from primitive types, whereas core reflection does not.
  • ‡ This package models all array types, whether their component type is generic or not, using the same ArArrayType. This is similar to how annotated array types are modeled in core reflection.
  • § In core reflection AnnotatedType is the root of the annotated type hierarchy. But it also used to represent an annotated type that is neither a type variable nor a parameterized type, nor an array, nor a wildcard. The table above indicates how that latter usage corresponds to this package.

Differences from Language Models

In Java's language model APIs, elements that represent types can only represent types defined in source code, thus excluding them for use in representing primitive and array types. But this package's ArClass can be used for declared type elements and for primitive and array types, much like the core reflection Class.

Unlike type mirrors, this package's ArType does not have a way to represent intersection or union types nor does it have a way to represent the "none" type (e.g. the super-type of Object), the null type (aka "bottom type") packages, or type signatures of methods and constructors. So its representation is more like core reflection in those regards. Furthermore, the void type is modeled as an ArPrimitiveType, like core reflection but unlike type mirrors.

The table below shows the type in this package that is used to model the same thing that a given language model type models:

ContextLanguage ModelsThis Package
Elements TypeElementArClass *
TypeParameterElementArTypeParameter
VariableElement †ArField
ArParameter
ExecutableElement ‡ArConstructor
ArMethod
PackageElementArPackage
Types DeclaredTypeArDeclaredType
PrimitiveTypeArPrimitiveType
NoType §
ArrayTypeArArrayType
WildcardTypeArWildcardType
TypeVariableArTypeVariable
ErrorType ‖None
ExecutableType ‖None
IntersectionType ‖None
NullType ‖None
UnionType ‖None
  • * As already stated, ArClass can represent primitive and array types, too. Such instances will have no corresponding TypeElement.
  • † Variable elements that are exception parameters, local variables, or try-with-resources variables are not modeled with types in this package. Variable elements that are enum constants or fields are both modeled with ArField.
  • ‡ Executable elements that are instance initialization blocks or static initializers are not modeled with types in this package.
  • § Type mirrors that represent the "none" type or packages are not modeled with types in this package. So the only NoType supported is void, which is considered a primitive type by this package. The "none" type is generally represented by a null instance in this package. Packages are treated like other unsupported kinds of type mirrors (see more below).
  • ‖ Like core reflection, various specialized kinds of type mirrors are not representable by this package. Attempts to wrap such a type mirror as an instance of ArType will result in a MirroredTypeException being thrown.

NOTE: APIs in this package requires the executing thread to be setup for the current processing environment. If you are running from the same thread on which the processor was invoked and the processor extends AbstractProcessor then this will have already been done for you.
